title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Part i

1 point(s) earned: For a representation of the electric field using vectors (not curved lines) that each have a component downward

1 point(s) earned: For accurately representing fringing near the edges and a uniform field near the middle (even if field lines are drawn instead of vectors, or the field has components upward instead of downward)

Part ii

1 point(s) earned: For a correct calculation of the charge

Q = C∆V = (ε0L2/d2)V0

Q = ε0L2V0/d2
descriptions:
The student response earns 0 of 3 point(s)

Part ii

Q = C∆V = (ε0L2/d2)V0

Q = ε0L2V0/d2

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Part i

1 point(s) earned: For indicating that since the battery remains connected, the potential difference across the capacitor remains the same

1 point(s) earned: For indicating that the electric field must decrease since E = ∆V/d and d has increased

Alternate Solution

C = kε0A/d

For reasoning that capacitance decreases as d increases

Q = C∆V

For reasoning that the potential difference across the capacitor remains the same and therefore the charge decreases

E = Q/ε0 A, so E decreases because Q decreases

Part ii

1 point(s) earned: For indicating that the charge on each plate is the same as in part (a)(ii)

1 point(s) earned: For reasoning that the electric field depends only on the magnitude of the charge, and therefore does not change (or has a change consistent with the change in charge indicated)

Examples:

The charge on the plates does not change, so E remains the same.

E = ∆V/d = Q/Cd. Since C ∝ 1/d, E is independent of the plate spacing which is the only thing that changes.

Alternate Solution

C = kε0A/d, so as d increases C decreases

∆V = Q/C

For recognizing that since charge is constant, as C decreases ∆V increases

E = ∆V/d

For reasoning that E does not change since ∆V and d increase by the same factor

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point(s) earned: For indicating that the potential difference is the same across each capacitor

1 point(s) earned: For indicating that C2 = 4C1

1 point(s) earned: For values of the charge on each capacitor consistent with the relationship between capacitances

Q1 = Q0, Q2 = 4Q0

Example: The conditions for C1 are the same as in part (a)(ii), so it has a charge Q0. The area of C2 is four times that of C1, so it has four times the capacitance. In order to have the same potential difference as C1, it must therefore have four times the charge.

Alternate Solution

For indicating the potential difference is the same across each capacitor

For indicating A2 = 4A1

For values of the charge on each capacitor consistent with the relationship between areas

Q1 = ε0V0L2/d2

Q2 = ε0V0(2L)2/d2
